conditions.name: Cesarean Section Wound Infection
conditions.shortDescription: Surgical site infection after cesarean delivery requiring antibiotics (cefazolin + metronidazole OR ampicillin-sulbactam) + wound care

content.definition: Surgical site infection (SSI) after cesarean delivery. Organisms: Staphylococcus aureus (30-40%, including MRSA 10-20%), Streptococcus (GBS, GAS, 15-20%), E. coli (15-20%), anaerobes (Bacteroides, 10-15%), Enterococcus (5-10%). Incidence: 3-15% of cesarean deliveries (higher if emergency cesarean, prolonged rupture of membranes, chorioamnionitis, obesity). Complications: Wound dehiscence (5-10%), necrotizing fasciitis (rare, <1%, high mortality), sepsis (5-10%).
content.clinical_presentation: Fever >38°C, wound erythema, warmth, swelling, purulent drainage, wound dehiscence (separation of incision). Physical exam: Erythema extending >2 cm from incision, warmth, induration, purulent drainage, fluctuance (if abscess), wound dehiscence. Fever is common (60-70%). Leukocytosis (WBC >10,000) common but non-specific. Onset: 4-7 days postpartum (superficial SSI), 7-30 days postpartum (deep SSI or organ/space SSI).
content.diagnostic_criteria: Clinical diagnosis (CDC 2024 SSI criteria): Superficial SSI (within 30 days, involves skin/subcutaneous tissue, purulent drainage OR positive culture + signs of infection). Deep SSI (within 30 days, involves fascia/muscle, purulent drainage OR abscess OR dehiscence). Organ/space SSI (within 30 days, involves organs/spaces other than incision, abscess OR positive culture).
risk_factors: Emergency cesarean delivery (most important risk factor, 2-3 fold increased risk)
Lack of prophylactic antibiotics (cefazolin 2g IV before skin incision reduces SSI by 50-70%)
red_flags: Necrotizing fasciitis - rare, rapidly progressive, crepitus, skin necrosis, severe pain, requires urgent surgical debridement + ICU + broad-spectrum antibiotics, mortality 20-30%
Wound dehiscence - separation of incision, requires surgical repair if fascia involved
Sepsis - hypotension, tachycardia >120 bpm, altered mental status, requires IV antibiotics + ICU
MRSA - community-acquired MRSA (CA-MRSA) 10-20%, requires vancomycin or linezolid

content.when_to_test: Clinical diagnosis (do NOT delay antibiotics while awaiting test results). Wound culture (if purulent drainage, positive in 60-70%, S. aureus most common). Blood cultures (if fever >38.5°C or sepsis suspected, positive in 10-20%). Imaging (CT or ultrasound) if deep SSI or abscess suspected.
essential_tests: Clinical diagnosis: Fever >38°C + wound erythema + warmth + purulent drainage. No tests required to start treatment.
Wound culture: If purulent drainage (positive in 60-70%, S. aureus most common, MRSA 10-20%). Collect before antibiotics. Use if recurrent SSI or failed initial therapy.
conditional_tests: Blood cultures x2: If fever >38.5°C or sepsis suspected (positive in 10-20%). Before antibiotics.
CBC: Leukocytosis (WBC >10,000, 60-70%). Non-specific, not required for diagnosis.
CT abdomen/pelvis with contrast: If deep SSI or abscess suspected (persistent fever despite antibiotics, palpable mass, wound dehiscence). Fluid collection, abscess, fascial dehiscence.
Ultrasound: If superficial abscess suspected (palpable mass, fluctuance). Fluid collection <3 cm (needle aspiration) or >3 cm (incision and drainage).
content.when_not_to_test: Do NOT delay antibiotics while awaiting test results (clinical diagnosis sufficient). Do NOT routinely culture if no purulent drainage (not needed). Do NOT routinely image if no signs of deep SSI or abscess (not needed).
content.turnaround_time: Wound culture: 24-48 hours. Blood cultures: 24-48 hours. CBC: 1-2 hours. CT abdomen/pelvis: Same day. Ultrasound: Same day.

content.organism: Staphylococcus aureus (30-40%, including MRSA 10-20%), Streptococcus (GBS, GAS, 15-20%), E. coli (15-20%), anaerobes (Bacteroides, 10-15%), Enterococcus (5-10%), Coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS, 5-10%, usually contaminant). MRSA: Community-acquired MRSA (CA-MRSA) 10-20% (increasing), associated with recurrent SSI and abscess formation.
content.pathogenesis: Skin flora (S. aureus, Streptococcus) OR vaginal flora (E. coli, anaerobes, Enterococcus) → contamination during surgery → bacterial overgrowth → inflammation → SSI. Risk factors: Emergency cesarean, prolonged rupture of membranes, prolonged labor, chorioamnionitis, obesity, diabetes, lack of prophylactic antibiotics. Complications: Wound dehiscence (5-10%), necrotizing fasciitis (rare, <1%), sepsis (5-10%).

resistance_patterns.mrsa_resistance: MRSA: Community-acquired MRSA (CA-MRSA) 10-20% (increasing). Resistant to beta-lactams (cefazolin, cephalexin). Susceptible to vancomycin (100%), linezolid (100%), TMP-SMX (95-98%), doxycycline (95-98%).
resistance_patterns.mssa_resistance: MSSA: Susceptible to cefazolin (100%), cephalexin (100%), dicloxacillin (100%).

content.timing_critical: Start antibiotics immediately upon diagnosis (do NOT delay for test results). Cefazolin 2g IV q8h + Metronidazole 500mg IV q8h (covers S. aureus, Streptococcus, E. coli, anaerobes) OR Ampicillin-sulbactam 3g IV q6h (single agent). Wound care: Open wound, debride necrotic tissue, pack with saline-soaked gauze, change dressing daily. Continue antibiotics until afebrile x 24-48 hours.

content.first_line: Cefazolin 2g IV q8h + Metronidazole 500mg IV q8h (covers S. aureus, Streptococcus, E. coli, anaerobes). Alternative: Ampicillin-sulbactam 3g IV q6h (single agent, covers S. aureus, Streptococcus, E. coli, anaerobes). Wound care: Open wound, debride necrotic tissue, pack with saline-soaked gauze, change dressing daily. Continue antibiotics until afebrile x 24-48 hours, then switch to PO.
content.mrsa_coverage: Add vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h if: MRSA risk factors (prior MRSA infection, nasal colonization, recurrent SSI), severe sepsis, or failed initial therapy. Alternative: Linezolid 600mg IV/PO BID (if vancomycin contraindicated or resistant). MRSA 10-20% of cesarean SSI.
content.penicillin_allergy: Clindamycin 900mg IV q8h + Gentamicin 5mg/kg IV daily (covers S. aureus, Streptococcus, E. coli, anaerobes). Alternative: Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h + Metronidazole 500mg IV q8h + Gentamicin 5mg/kg IV daily (if severe penicillin allergy).
content.wound_care: Open wound (remove staples or sutures, allow drainage). Debride necrotic tissue (sharp debridement if needed). Pack wound with saline-soaked gauze (change dressing daily or BID). Negative pressure wound therapy (wound VAC) if large wound (>5 cm) or deep SSI. Delayed primary closure or secondary intention healing after infection resolved.
content.avoid_list: Do NOT delay antibiotics while awaiting test results. Do NOT close infected wound (increases abscess formation). Do NOT use antibiotics alone without wound care (insufficient).

content.mssa_ssi: Cefazolin 2g IV q8h OR Cephalexin 500mg PO QID (covers MSSA, 100% susceptible). Continue until afebrile x 24-48 hours, then switch to PO x 5-7 days total.
content.mrsa_ssi: Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h (covers MRSA, 100% susceptible). Alternative: Linezolid 600mg IV/PO BID. Continue until afebrile x 24-48 hours, then switch to PO (TMP-SMX DS 1-2 tabs PO BID OR Doxycycline 100mg PO BID OR Linezolid 600mg PO BID) x 5-7 days total.
content.streptococcal_ssi: Penicillin VK 500mg PO QID OR Amoxicillin 500mg PO TID (covers Streptococcus, 100% susceptible). Continue x 5-7 days total.
content.polymicrobial_ssi: Ampicillin-sulbactam 3g IV q6h OR Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875mg PO BID (covers S. aureus, Streptococcus, E. coli, anaerobes). Continue until afebrile x 24-48 hours, then switch to PO x 5-7 days total.
content.wound_care: Open wound, debride necrotic tissue, pack with saline-soaked gauze, change dressing daily. Negative pressure wound therapy (wound VAC) if large wound (>5 cm) or deep SSI. Delayed primary closure (after infection resolved, 7-14 days) OR Secondary intention healing (allow wound to heal from bottom up, 4-8 weeks).
content.duration: IV antibiotics until afebrile x 24-48 hours, then switch to PO x 5-7 days total. Wound care: Continue until wound healed (4-8 weeks for secondary intention healing).

content.standard_duration: IV antibiotics until afebrile x 24-48 hours, then switch to PO x 5-7 days total. Wound care: Continue until wound healed (4-8 weeks for secondary intention healing). Most patients improve within 48-72 hours of antibiotics + wound care.
content.monitoring: Follow-up in 48-72 hours (assess clinical improvement). Wound care: Change dressing daily or BID, assess for healing. Imaging (CT or ultrasound) if no improvement (rule out deep SSI or abscess). Monitor for complications (wound dehiscence, necrotizing fasciitis, sepsis).
content.stop_criteria: Discontinue antibiotics when afebrile x 24-48 hours AND wound improving (decreased erythema, decreased drainage). Total duration: 5-7 days. Continue wound care until wound healed (4-8 weeks for secondary intention healing).

content.wound_dehiscence: Separation of incision. Superficial dehiscence (skin/subcutaneous tissue only): Continue wound care (open wound, pack with gauze, delayed primary closure or secondary intention healing). Deep dehiscence (fascia involved): Requires surgical repair (return to OR, re-suture fascia). Gynecology consult.
content.necrotizing_fasciitis: Rare (<1%), rapidly progressive, high mortality (20-30%). Clinical: Crepitus, skin necrosis, severe pain out of proportion to exam, sepsis. CT abdomen/pelvis: Gas in soft tissues. Management: Urgent surgical debridement (return to OR, wide excision of necrotic tissue), broad-spectrum antibiotics (vancomycin + piperacillin-tazobactam + clindamycin), ICU admission. Gynecology + general surgery consult.
content.abscess: Palpable mass, fluctuance. Ultrasound: Fluid collection. Management: Incision and drainage (I&D) if abscess >3 cm OR Needle aspiration if abscess <3 cm. Continue antibiotics x 5-7 days after drainage. Continue wound care until healed.
content.mrsa_ssi: Community-acquired MRSA (CA-MRSA) 10-20% (increasing). Risk factors: Prior MRSA infection, nasal colonization, recurrent SSI. Treatment: Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h OR Linezolid 600mg IV/PO BID. Decolonization (if recurrent): Mupirocin nasal ointment BID x 5 days + chlorhexidine body wash daily x 5 days.
content.breastfeeding: Most antibiotics safe in breastfeeding: Cefazolin, cephalexin, ampicillin-sulbactam, amoxicillin-clavulanate, clindamycin, vancomycin, TMP-SMX (minimal excretion in breast milk). Avoid doxycycline (excreted in breast milk, may affect infant bone/teeth). Continue breastfeeding during treatment.
content.counseling: Cesarean SSI is common (3-15% of cesarean deliveries). Most cases respond to antibiotics + wound care within 48-72 hours. Wound healing: 4-8 weeks for secondary intention healing. Delayed primary closure (after infection resolved, 7-14 days) may shorten healing time. Future pregnancies: No increased risk of SSI (not a chronic condition). Prevention: Prophylactic antibiotics before cesarean (cefazolin 2g IV before skin incision) reduce SSI by 50-70%.

de_escalation_opportunities: Start antibiotics immediately upon diagnosis (do NOT delay for test results, clinical diagnosis sufficient)
Cefazolin 2g IV q8h + Metronidazole 500mg IV q8h OR Ampicillin-sulbactam 3g IV q6h (covers S. aureus, Streptococcus, E. coli, anaerobes)
Do NOT routinely add vancomycin (MRSA 10-20%, use only if MRSA risk factors or failed initial therapy)
Discontinue IV antibiotics when afebrile x 24-48 hours, then switch to PO x 5-7 days total
Wound care REQUIRED (antibiotics alone insufficient)
timeout_checklist: Is diagnosis confirmed by clinical criteria? (Fever >38°C + wound erythema + warmth + purulent drainage)
Are antibiotics started immediately? (Cefazolin + metronidazole OR ampicillin-sulbactam)
Is wound care initiated? (Open wound, debride necrotic tissue, pack with gauze, change dressing daily)
Is MRSA suspected? (Prior MRSA infection, recurrent SSI, failed initial therapy → vancomycin)
Is deep SSI or abscess ruled out? (Imaging if persistent fever or palpable mass)
Is patient afebrile x 24-48 hours? (If yes, switch to PO antibiotics x 5-7 days total)
content.avoid_unnecessary_treatment: Avoid vancomycin unless MRSA suspected (10-20%). Do NOT delay antibiotics while awaiting test results. Do NOT close infected wound (increases abscess formation). Do NOT use antibiotics alone without wound care (insufficient). Do NOT continue IV antibiotics beyond 48 hours if afebrile (no benefit, increases resistance).
content.diagnostic_stewardship: Clinical diagnosis (fever >38°C + wound erythema + warmth + purulent drainage). Wound culture if purulent drainage (positive in 60-70%, S. aureus most common). Blood cultures if fever >38.5°C or sepsis suspected. Imaging (CT or ultrasound) if deep SSI or abscess suspected. Do NOT routinely culture if no purulent drainage.
content.prevention: Prophylactic antibiotics before cesarean delivery (cefazolin 2g IV before skin incision OR cefazolin 3g IV if weight >120 kg) reduce SSI by 50-70%. Chlorhexidine-alcohol skin prep (reduces SSI by 40-50% vs povidone-iodine). Maintain normothermia during surgery. Minimize operative time. Avoid subcutaneous drain (no benefit, may increase SSI).

conditions.name: Pyelonephritis (Pregnancy)
conditions.shortDescription: Upper urinary tract infection in pregnancy requiring hospitalization + IV antibiotics (ceftriaxone OR cefazolin + gentamicin) until afebrile x 24-48 hours

content.definition: Upper urinary tract infection (kidney infection) in pregnancy. Organisms: E. coli (70-80%), Klebsiella (10-15%), Proteus (5-10%), Enterococcus (5-10%). Incidence: 1-2% of pregnancies (higher if untreated asymptomatic bacteriuria). Complications: Preterm labor (10-20%), sepsis (5-10%), acute kidney injury (5-10%), ARDS (1-2%), maternal mortality (rare, <0.1%).
content.clinical_presentation: Fever >38°C, flank pain (unilateral or bilateral), costovertebral angle (CVA) tenderness, nausea, vomiting, dysuria, frequency, urgency. Physical exam: Fever, tachycardia (>100 bpm), CVA tenderness (positive Murphy's punch sign), uterine contractions (if preterm labor). Fever is REQUIRED for diagnosis. Leukocytosis (WBC >10,000) common but non-specific.
content.diagnostic_criteria: Clinical diagnosis: Fever >38°C + flank pain + CVA tenderness in pregnant woman. Laboratory: Pyuria (WBC >10 per HPF, 90-95%), bacteriuria (>100,000 CFU/mL, 80-90%), positive urine culture (E. coli most common). Blood cultures (positive in 15-20%). Urinalysis: Pyuria, bacteriuria, WBC casts (pathognomonic for pyelonephritis).
risk_factors: Untreated asymptomatic bacteriuria (most important risk factor, 20-40% progress to pyelonephritis if untreated)
Urinary tract abnormalities (vesicoureteral reflux, kidney stones)
red_flags: Sepsis - hypotension, tachycardia >120 bpm, altered mental status, requires ICU + vasopressors
Preterm labor - uterine contractions, cervical dilation, requires tocolytics + corticosteroids if <34 weeks
Acute kidney injury - oliguria, elevated creatinine, requires dialysis if severe
ARDS - respiratory distress, hypoxemia, requires mechanical ventilation
Urosepsis - high mortality (1-2%), requires aggressive fluid resuscitation + broad-spectrum antibiotics

content.when_to_test: Test if: Fever >38°C + flank pain + CVA tenderness in pregnant woman. Do NOT delay antibiotics while awaiting test results (clinical diagnosis sufficient). Urinalysis and urine culture before antibiotics (positive in 80-90%). Blood cultures before antibiotics (positive in 15-20%).
essential_tests: Temperature: Fever >38°C (100.4°F) REQUIRED for diagnosis. Measure every 4 hours.
Physical exam: CVA tenderness (positive Murphy's punch sign), flank pain.
Urinalysis: Pyuria (WBC >10 per HPF, 90-95%), bacteriuria (>100,000 CFU/mL, 80-90%), WBC casts (pathognomonic for pyelonephritis, 50-60%), nitrites (positive in 50-60% if E. coli).
Urine culture: Before antibiotics. Positive in 80-90% (E. coli most common, 70-80%). Turnaround: 24-48 hours.
Blood cultures x2: Before antibiotics. Positive in 15-20% (E. coli most common). Turnaround: 24-48 hours.
conditional_tests: CBC: Leukocytosis (WBC >10,000, 70-80%). Non-specific, not required for diagnosis.
Creatinine, BUN: If acute kidney injury suspected (oliguria, elevated creatinine). Creatinine >1.2 mg/dL abnormal in pregnancy (normal 0.4-0.8 mg/dL).
Renal ultrasound: If no improvement after 48-72 hours of antibiotics (rule out kidney stone, abscess, obstruction). Hydronephrosis common in pregnancy (physiologic, not pathologic).
Fetal monitoring: If preterm (<37 weeks) or uterine contractions. Continuous fetal heart rate monitoring, tocodynamometry (assess for preterm labor).
content.when_not_to_test: Do NOT delay antibiotics while awaiting test results (clinical diagnosis sufficient). Do NOT routinely image if clinical improvement after 48-72 hours (not needed). Do NOT require positive blood cultures for diagnosis (positive in only 15-20%).
content.turnaround_time: Urinalysis: 1-2 hours. Urine culture: 24-48 hours. Blood cultures: 24-48 hours. CBC: 1-2 hours. Creatinine: 1-2 hours. Renal ultrasound: Same day.

content.organism: E. coli (70-80%), Klebsiella (10-15%), Proteus (5-10%), Enterococcus (5-10%), Staphylococcus saprophyticus (1-2%, rare in pregnancy). E. coli: Most common cause of pyelonephritis in pregnancy. Ampicillin resistance 30-50% (increasing). Ceftriaxone resistance <5%. Gentamicin resistance <5%.
content.pathogenesis: Ascending infection from bladder → ureters → kidneys. Pregnancy-related factors: Progesterone-induced ureteral dilation and decreased peristalsis → urinary stasis → bacterial overgrowth. Untreated asymptomatic bacteriuria (20-40% progress to pyelonephritis if untreated). Complications: Preterm labor (10-20%, endotoxin-induced uterine contractions), sepsis (5-10%), acute kidney injury (5-10%), ARDS (1-2%).

resistance_patterns.e_coli_resistance: E. coli: Ampicillin resistance 30-50% (increasing). Ceftriaxone resistance <5%. Gentamicin resistance <5%. Nitrofurantoin resistance <5% (but avoid in third trimester, risk of hemolytic anemia in newborn).
resistance_patterns.klebsiella_resistance: Klebsiella: Ampicillin resistance 100% (intrinsic). Ceftriaxone resistance <5%. Gentamicin resistance <5%.
resistance_patterns.enterococcus_resistance: Enterococcus: Ceftriaxone resistance 100% (intrinsic). Ampicillin 100% susceptible. Vancomycin 100% susceptible.

content.timing_critical: Start antibiotics immediately upon diagnosis (do NOT delay for test results). Hospitalization REQUIRED (IV antibiotics, IV fluids, fetal monitoring). Ceftriaxone 2g IV daily (covers E. coli, Klebsiella, Proteus) OR Cefazolin 2g IV q8h + Gentamicin 5mg/kg IV daily (broader coverage). Continue until afebrile x 24-48 hours, then switch to PO x 10-14 days total.

content.first_line: Ceftriaxone 2g IV daily (covers E. coli, Klebsiella, Proteus, preferred for once-daily dosing). Alternative: Cefazolin 2g IV q8h + Gentamicin 5mg/kg IV daily (broader coverage, covers Enterococcus). Hospitalization REQUIRED. IV fluids (2-3 L crystalloid over 24 hours, maintain urine output >0.5 mL/kg/h). Continue until afebrile x 24-48 hours, then switch to PO x 10-14 days total.
content.alternative: Ampicillin-sulbactam 3g IV q6h (covers E. coli, Klebsiella, Enterococcus, but E. coli ampicillin resistance 30-50%). Piperacillin-tazobactam 3.375g IV q6h (broad-spectrum, covers E. coli, Klebsiella, Proteus, Enterococcus, Pseudomonas).
content.penicillin_allergy: Gentamicin 5mg/kg IV daily + Aztreonam 2g IV q8h (covers E. coli, Klebsiella, Proteus). Alternative: Gentamicin 5mg/kg IV daily + Vancomycin 15-20mg/kg IV q8-12h (if Enterococcus suspected).
content.preterm_labor: If uterine contractions (preterm labor): Tocolytics (nifedipine 10-20mg PO q4-6h OR indomethacin 50mg PR x1, then 25mg PO q6h if <32 weeks). Corticosteroids (betamethasone 12mg IM x2 doses 24 hours apart OR dexamethasone 6mg IM q12h x4 doses) if <34 weeks (fetal lung maturity). Continue antibiotics.
content.avoid_list: Avoid fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, contraindicated in pregnancy). Avoid tetracyclines (doxycycline, contraindicated in pregnancy). Avoid nitrofurantoin in third trimester (risk of hemolytic anemia in newborn). Avoid aminoglycosides (gentamicin) for prolonged duration (>5-7 days, ototoxicity, nephrotoxicity).

content.e_coli_pyelonephritis: Ceftriaxone 2g IV daily (covers E. coli, ampicillin resistance 30-50%). Continue until afebrile x 24-48 hours, then switch to PO (cephalexin 500mg PO QID OR amoxicillin-clavulanate 875mg PO BID) x 10-14 days total.
content.klebsiella_pyelonephritis: Ceftriaxone 2g IV daily (covers Klebsiella, ampicillin resistance 100%). Continue until afebrile x 24-48 hours, then switch to PO (cephalexin 500mg PO QID OR amoxicillin-clavulanate 875mg PO BID) x 10-14 days total.
content.enterococcus_pyelonephritis: Ampicillin 2g IV q6h (covers Enterococcus, 100% susceptible). Continue until afebrile x 24-48 hours, then switch to PO (amoxicillin 500mg PO TID) x 10-14 days total.
content.treatment_failure: No improvement after 48-72 hours of antibiotics. Causes: Resistant organism (ESBL, AmpC), kidney stone, abscess, obstruction. Management: Renal ultrasound (rule out kidney stone, abscess, obstruction). Broaden antibiotics (piperacillin-tazobactam OR meropenem if ESBL suspected). Urology consult if kidney stone or obstruction.
content.duration: IV antibiotics until afebrile x 24-48 hours, then switch to PO x 10-14 days total. Total duration: 10-14 days. PO antibiotics: Cephalexin 500mg PO QID OR Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875mg PO BID OR Nitrofurantoin 100mg PO BID (avoid in third trimester).

content.standard_duration: IV antibiotics until afebrile x 24-48 hours, then switch to PO x 10-14 days total. Total duration: 10-14 days. Most patients improve within 48-72 hours of IV antibiotics. Hospitalization: 2-4 days (until afebrile x 24-48 hours).
content.monitoring: Monitor temperature every 4 hours. Monitor urine output (maintain >0.5 mL/kg/h). Monitor for clinical improvement (decreased flank pain, decreased CVA tenderness). Monitor for complications (preterm labor, sepsis, acute kidney injury). Fetal monitoring if preterm (<37 weeks) or uterine contractions. Repeat urine culture 1-2 weeks after completion of antibiotics (test of cure, ensure eradication).
content.stop_criteria: Discontinue IV antibiotics when afebrile x 24-48 hours, then switch to PO x 10-14 days total. Complete 10-14 days of antibiotics (prevent recurrence and chronic pyelonephritis). Repeat urine culture 1-2 weeks after completion of antibiotics (test of cure).

content.preterm_labor: Pyelonephritis increases risk of preterm labor (10-20%, endotoxin-induced uterine contractions). Management: Tocolytics (nifedipine 10-20mg PO q4-6h OR indomethacin 50mg PR x1, then 25mg PO q6h if <32 weeks). Corticosteroids (betamethasone 12mg IM x2 doses 24 hours apart OR dexamethasone 6mg IM q12h x4 doses) if <34 weeks (fetal lung maturity). Continue antibiotics. Obstetrics consult.
content.sepsis: Hypotension (SBP <90 mmHg), tachycardia (>120 bpm), altered mental status, oliguria (<0.5 mL/kg/h). Management: ICU admission, aggressive fluid resuscitation (2-3 L crystalloid), vasopressors (norepinephrine 0.05-0.5 mcg/kg/min), broad-spectrum antibiotics (piperacillin-tazobactam 3.375g IV q6h OR meropenem 1g IV q8h). Mortality 1-2% if treated promptly.
content.acute_kidney_injury: Oliguria (<0.5 mL/kg/h), elevated creatinine (>1.2 mg/dL abnormal in pregnancy). Management: IV fluids (maintain urine output >0.5 mL/kg/h), avoid nephrotoxic drugs (NSAIDs, aminoglycosides), monitor creatinine daily. Dialysis if severe (creatinine >5 mg/dL, oliguria despite fluids). Nephrology consult.
content.recurrent_pyelonephritis: Recurrence rate 5-10% during same pregnancy. Causes: Resistant organism, kidney stone, urinary tract abnormality, inadequate antibiotic duration. Prevention: Suppressive antibiotics (nitrofurantoin 100mg PO daily OR cephalexin 250mg PO daily) for remainder of pregnancy. Renal ultrasound (rule out kidney stone, urinary tract abnormality). Urology consult if recurrent.
content.asymptomatic_bacteriuria_screening: Universal screening at first prenatal visit (12-16 weeks gestation). Urine culture (positive if >100,000 CFU/mL). Treatment: Nitrofurantoin 100mg PO BID x 5-7 days OR Cephalexin 500mg PO QID x 5-7 days OR Amoxicillin-clavulanate 875mg PO BID x 5-7 days. Reduces pyelonephritis by 70-80%. Repeat urine culture 1-2 weeks after treatment (test of cure).
content.counseling: Pyelonephritis in pregnancy requires hospitalization (IV antibiotics, IV fluids, fetal monitoring). Most patients improve within 48-72 hours. Complete 10-14 days of antibiotics (prevent recurrence). Repeat urine culture 1-2 weeks after completion (test of cure). Future pregnancies: Increased risk of recurrence (5-10%), requires suppressive antibiotics. Prevention: Treat asymptomatic bacteriuria (reduces pyelonephritis by 70-80%).

Hospitalization REQUIRED (IV antibiotics, IV fluids, fetal monitoring)
Ceftriaxone 2g IV daily (preferred, once-daily dosing) OR Cefazolin 2g IV q8h + Gentamicin 5mg/kg IV daily
Discontinue IV antibiotics when afebrile x 24-48 hours, then switch to PO x 10-14 days total
Repeat urine culture 1-2 weeks after completion (test of cure)

Are antibiotics started immediately? (Ceftriaxone 2g IV daily OR cefazolin + gentamicin)
Is patient hospitalized? (IV antibiotics, IV fluids, fetal monitoring REQUIRED)
Are urine culture and blood cultures obtained before antibiotics? (Positive in 80-90% and 15-20% respectively)
Is patient afebrile x 24-48 hours? (If yes, switch to PO antibiotics x 10-14 days total)
Is preterm labor ruled out? (Fetal monitoring if preterm or uterine contractions)
Is repeat urine culture planned? (1-2 weeks after completion, test of cure)
content.avoid_unnecessary_treatment: Avoid fluoroquinolones (contraindicated in pregnancy). Avoid tetracyclines (contraindicated in pregnancy). Avoid nitrofurantoin in third trimester (risk of hemolytic anemia in newborn). Avoid aminoglycosides for prolonged duration (>5-7 days, ototoxicity, nephrotoxicity). Do NOT delay antibiotics while awaiting test results. Do NOT treat as outpatient (hospitalization REQUIRED).
content.diagnostic_stewardship: Clinical diagnosis (fever >38°C + flank pain + CVA tenderness in pregnant woman). Urinalysis and urine culture before antibiotics (positive in 80-90%). Blood cultures before antibiotics (positive in 15-20%). Renal ultrasound if no improvement after 48-72 hours (rule out kidney stone, abscess, obstruction). Do NOT routinely image if clinical improvement.
content.prevention: Universal screening for asymptomatic bacteriuria at first prenatal visit (12-16 weeks gestation). Treatment of asymptomatic bacteriuria reduces pyelonephritis by 70-80%. Suppressive antibiotics (nitrofurantoin 100mg PO daily OR cephalexin 250mg PO daily) for remainder of pregnancy if recurrent pyelonephritis.

conditions.name: Listeriosis (Pregnancy)
conditions.shortDescription: Life-threatening foodborne infection in pregnancy requiring IV ampicillin + gentamicin x 14-21 days (high risk of fetal loss, neonatal sepsis, meningitis)

content.definition: Life-threatening foodborne infection caused by Listeria monocytogenes. Pregnant women are 10-20 times more likely to develop listeriosis than general population (cell-mediated immunity suppressed in pregnancy). Incidence: 12 cases per 100,000 pregnancies (rare but serious). Complications: Fetal loss (20-30%, miscarriage or stillbirth), preterm labor (30-40%), neonatal sepsis (50-60%), neonatal meningitis (10-20%), maternal death (rare, <1%).
content.clinical_presentation: Maternal: Fever >38°C, flu-like symptoms (myalgia, chills, headache, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea), bacteremia (positive blood cultures 70-80%). Often mild or asymptomatic in mother but severe in fetus/neonate. Neonatal: Early-onset (onset <7 days, transplacental transmission): Sepsis, pneumonia, disseminated granulomatosis. Late-onset (onset 7-28 days, nosocomial transmission): Meningitis (most common).
content.diagnostic_criteria: Clinical diagnosis: Fever >38°C + flu-like symptoms + history of high-risk food exposure (deli meats, soft cheeses, unpasteurized dairy) in pregnant woman. Laboratory: Positive blood cultures (70-80%, Listeria monocytogenes). Positive amniotic fluid culture (if amniocentesis performed). Positive neonatal blood/CSF culture (if neonatal infection). Listeria: Gram-positive rod, beta-hemolytic, tumbling motility.
risk_factors: Pregnancy (most important risk factor, 10-20 times increased risk vs general population)
High-risk food exposure (deli meats, hot dogs, soft cheeses, unpasteurized dairy, smoked seafood, raw sprouts)
Hispanic ethnicity (higher incidence, possibly related to dietary habits)
red_flags: Fetal loss - miscarriage (20-30% if first/second trimester) or stillbirth (20-30% if third trimester), requires delivery + IV antibiotics
Preterm labor - uterine contractions, cervical dilation (30-40%), requires tocolytics + corticosteroids if <34 weeks
Neonatal sepsis - fever, respiratory distress, hypotension (50-60%), requires neonatal ICU + IV antibiotics (ampicillin + gentamicin)
Neonatal meningitis - lethargy, poor feeding, seizures (10-20%), requires neonatal ICU + IV antibiotics x 21 days, mortality 20-30%
Maternal sepsis - hypotension, altered mental status (rare, <5%), requires ICU + vasopressors

content.when_to_test: Test if: Fever >38°C + flu-like symptoms + history of high-risk food exposure in pregnant woman. Do NOT delay antibiotics while awaiting test results (life-threatening to fetus). Blood cultures before antibiotics (positive in 70-80%). Amniocentesis (if fetal distress, consider amniotic fluid culture). Neonatal blood/CSF culture (if neonatal infection suspected).
essential_tests: Temperature: Fever >38°C (100.4°F) common (70-80%). Measure every 4 hours.
Blood cultures x2: Before antibiotics. Positive in 70-80% (Listeria monocytogenes). Turnaround: 24-48 hours. Listeria: Gram-positive rod, beta-hemolytic, tumbling motility.
Fetal monitoring: Continuous fetal heart rate monitoring (assess for fetal distress). Non-reassuring fetal heart rate tracing (late decelerations, decreased variability) suggests fetal infection.
conditional_tests: CBC: Leukocytosis (WBC >10,000, 60-70%). Non-specific, not required for diagnosis.

Amniocentesis: If fetal distress (non-reassuring fetal heart rate tracing). Amniotic fluid culture (positive in 50-60% if fetal infection). Amniotic fluid Gram stain (Gram-positive rods). Obstetrics consult before amniocentesis.
Neonatal blood culture: If neonatal infection suspected (fever, respiratory distress, hypotension). Positive in 50-60% (Listeria monocytogenes).

Neonatal CSF culture: If neonatal meningitis suspected (lethargy, poor feeding, seizures). Positive in 10-20% (Listeria monocytogenes). CSF: Elevated WBC (>100 cells/μL), elevated protein (>100 mg/dL), low glucose (<40 mg/dL).
Placental pathology: If fetal loss or preterm delivery. Microabscesses, chorioamnionitis, funisitis.
content.when_not_to_test: Do NOT delay antibiotics while awaiting test results (life-threatening to fetus). Do NOT routinely perform amniocentesis if no fetal distress (invasive, risk of preterm labor). Do NOT require positive blood cultures for diagnosis (positive in only 70-80%).
content.turnaround_time: Blood cultures: 24-48 hours (preliminary), 5 days (final). Amniotic fluid culture: 24-48 hours. Neonatal blood/CSF culture: 24-48 hours. CBC: 1-2 hours.

content.organism: Listeria monocytogenes. Gram-positive rod (coccobacillus), facultative intracellular pathogen, beta-hemolytic, tumbling motility (characteristic). Foodborne transmission: Deli meats, hot dogs, soft cheeses (queso fresco, brie, camembert), unpasteurized dairy, smoked seafood, raw sprouts. Can grow at refrigerator temperatures (4°C, cold-enrichment). Pregnant women 10-20 times more likely to develop listeriosis (cell-mediated immunity suppressed in pregnancy).
content.pathogenesis: Foodborne transmission → maternal bacteremia → transplacental transmission → fetal infection → fetal loss (20-30%), preterm labor (30-40%), neonatal sepsis (50-60%), neonatal meningitis (10-20%). Maternal symptoms often mild (fever, flu-like symptoms) but severe in fetus/neonate. Early-onset neonatal listeriosis (onset <7 days, transplacental transmission): Sepsis, pneumonia, disseminated granulomatosis. Late-onset neonatal listeriosis (onset 7-28 days, nosocomial transmission): Meningitis (most common).

resistance_patterns.ampicillin_resistance: Listeria: Ampicillin 100% susceptible (first-line). Penicillin G 100% susceptible (alternative).
resistance_patterns.gentamicin_resistance: Listeria: Gentamicin synergistic with ampicillin (combination therapy preferred). Gentamicin alone insufficient (poor intracellular penetration).
resistance_patterns.cephalosporin_resistance: Listeria: Cephalosporin resistance 100% (intrinsic). Do NOT use ceftriaxone or cefazolin (ineffective).
resistance_patterns.tmp_smx_resistance: Listeria: TMP-SMX 100% susceptible (alternative if penicillin allergy).

content.timing_critical: Start antibiotics immediately upon diagnosis (do NOT delay for test results, life-threatening to fetus). Hospitalization REQUIRED. Ampicillin 2g IV q4h + Gentamicin 5mg/kg IV daily x 14-21 days (combination therapy preferred, synergistic). Fetal monitoring (continuous fetal heart rate monitoring). Delivery if fetal distress (non-reassuring fetal heart rate tracing). Neonatal antibiotics (ampicillin + gentamicin) if neonatal infection suspected.

content.first_line: Ampicillin 2g IV q4h + Gentamicin 5mg/kg IV daily x 14-21 days (combination therapy preferred, synergistic, covers Listeria 100%). Hospitalization REQUIRED. Fetal monitoring (continuous fetal heart rate monitoring). Delivery if fetal distress (non-reassuring fetal heart rate tracing). Neonatal antibiotics (ampicillin 50mg/kg IV q12h + gentamicin 4mg/kg IV daily) if neonatal infection suspected.
content.alternative: Penicillin G 4 million units IV q4h + Gentamicin 5mg/kg IV daily x 14-21 days (alternative to ampicillin, Listeria 100% susceptible). TMP-SMX DS (160/800mg) 1-2 tabs IV q12h x 14-21 days (if penicillin allergy, Listeria 100% susceptible).
content.penicillin_allergy: TMP-SMX DS (160/800mg) 1-2 tabs IV q12h x 14-21 days (Listeria 100% susceptible). Alternative: Meropenem 2g IV q8h x 14-21 days (if severe penicillin allergy, Listeria susceptible). Do NOT use cephalosporins (ceftriaxone, cefazolin, Listeria resistance 100%).
content.neonatal_treatment: Ampicillin 50mg/kg IV q12h (if <7 days old) OR 50mg/kg IV q8h (if >7 days old) + Gentamicin 4mg/kg IV daily x 14-21 days (if sepsis) OR x 21 days (if meningitis). Neonatal ICU admission. Repeat neonatal CSF culture at 48 hours (ensure sterilization). Mortality 20-30% if neonatal meningitis.
content.avoid_list: Avoid cephalosporins (ceftriaxone, cefazolin, Listeria resistance 100%, ineffective). Do NOT delay antibiotics while awaiting test results (life-threatening to fetus). Do NOT use gentamicin alone (poor intracellular penetration, insufficient).

content.maternal_listeriosis: Ampicillin 2g IV q4h + Gentamicin 5mg/kg IV daily x 14-21 days (combination therapy preferred, synergistic). Continue until blood cultures negative x 48 hours AND afebrile x 48 hours. Total duration: 14-21 days (longer if fetal/neonatal infection).
content.neonatal_sepsis: Ampicillin 50mg/kg IV q12h (if <7 days old) OR 50mg/kg IV q8h (if >7 days old) + Gentamicin 4mg/kg IV daily x 14-21 days. Neonatal ICU admission. Repeat neonatal blood culture at 48 hours (ensure sterilization). Discontinue antibiotics when blood cultures negative x 48 hours AND clinically improved.
content.neonatal_meningitis: Ampicillin 50mg/kg IV q6h (higher dose for meningitis, better CSF penetration) + Gentamicin 4mg/kg IV daily x 21 days (minimum). Neonatal ICU admission. Repeat neonatal CSF culture at 48 hours (ensure sterilization). Continue antibiotics x 21 days total (longer duration for meningitis). Mortality 20-30%.
content.fetal_loss: If fetal loss (miscarriage or stillbirth): Delivery REQUIRED (remove infected tissue). Continue maternal antibiotics (ampicillin + gentamicin) x 14 days after delivery. Placental pathology (microabscesses, chorioamnionitis, funisitis). Counseling: Future pregnancies not contraindicated (not a chronic infection).
content.duration: Maternal: 14-21 days total (longer if fetal/neonatal infection). Neonatal sepsis: 14-21 days. Neonatal meningitis: 21 days (minimum). Continue until blood/CSF cultures negative x 48 hours AND clinically improved.

content.standard_duration: Maternal: 14-21 days total (longer if fetal/neonatal infection). Neonatal sepsis: 14-21 days. Neonatal meningitis: 21 days (minimum). Continue until blood/CSF cultures negative x 48 hours AND clinically improved. Hospitalization: 7-14 days (maternal), 14-21 days (neonatal sepsis), 21-28 days (neonatal meningitis).
content.monitoring: Maternal: Monitor temperature every 4 hours. Monitor for clinical improvement (decreased fever, improved symptoms). Fetal monitoring (continuous fetal heart rate monitoring, assess for fetal distress). Repeat blood cultures at 48 hours (ensure sterilization). Neonatal: Monitor for signs of infection (fever, respiratory distress, hypotension, lethargy, poor feeding, seizures). Repeat neonatal blood/CSF culture at 48 hours (ensure sterilization). Neonatal ICU admission.
content.stop_criteria: Maternal: Discontinue antibiotics when blood cultures negative x 48 hours AND afebrile x 48 hours AND 14-21 days completed. Neonatal: Discontinue antibiotics when blood/CSF cultures negative x 48 hours AND clinically improved AND 14-21 days completed (sepsis) OR 21 days completed (meningitis).

content.fetal_loss: Fetal loss (miscarriage or stillbirth) occurs in 20-30% of pregnancy-associated listeriosis. Higher risk if first/second trimester (20-30% miscarriage) or third trimester (20-30% stillbirth). Management: Delivery REQUIRED (remove infected tissue). Continue maternal antibiotics (ampicillin + gentamicin) x 14 days after delivery. Placental pathology (microabscesses, chorioamnionitis, funisitis). Counseling: Future pregnancies not contraindicated (not a chronic infection).
content.preterm_labor: Preterm labor occurs in 30-40% of pregnancy-associated listeriosis (endotoxin-induced uterine contractions). Management: Tocolytics (nifedipine 10-20mg PO q4-6h OR indomethacin 50mg PR x1, then 25mg PO q6h if <32 weeks). Corticosteroids (betamethasone 12mg IM x2 doses 24 hours apart OR dexamethasone 6mg IM q12h x4 doses) if <34 weeks (fetal lung maturity). Continue antibiotics. Obstetrics consult.
content.neonatal_sepsis: Neonatal sepsis occurs in 50-60% of pregnancy-associated listeriosis. Early-onset (onset <7 days, transplacental transmission): Sepsis, pneumonia, disseminated granulomatosis. Late-onset (onset 7-28 days, nosocomial transmission): Meningitis (most common). Management: Neonatal ICU admission, ampicillin 50mg/kg IV q12h + gentamicin 4mg/kg IV daily x 14-21 days. Mortality 20-30% if meningitis.
content.neonatal_meningitis: Neonatal meningitis occurs in 10-20% of pregnancy-associated listeriosis. Late-onset (onset 7-28 days, nosocomial transmission). Clinical: Lethargy, poor feeding, seizures, bulging fontanelle. CSF: Elevated WBC (>100 cells/μL), elevated protein (>100 mg/dL), low glucose (<40 mg/dL). Management: Neonatal ICU admission, ampicillin 50mg/kg IV q6h + gentamicin 4mg/kg IV daily x 21 days (minimum). Repeat CSF culture at 48 hours (ensure sterilization). Mortality 20-30%.
content.food_safety_counseling: Pregnant women should avoid high-risk foods: Deli meats and hot dogs (unless heated to steaming), soft cheeses (queso fresco, brie, camembert, blue cheese, feta, unless labeled pasteurized), unpasteurized dairy (raw milk, raw milk cheese), smoked seafood (lox, nova, kippered, unless canned or shelf-stable), raw sprouts (alfalfa, bean, clover). Safe alternatives: Hard cheeses (cheddar, Swiss, parmesan), pasteurized dairy, canned seafood, cooked sprouts. Listeria can grow at refrigerator temperatures (4°C), so refrigeration does NOT prevent growth.
content.counseling: Listeriosis in pregnancy is life-threatening to fetus (fetal loss 20-30%, neonatal sepsis 50-60%, neonatal meningitis 10-20%). Requires hospitalization + IV antibiotics x 14-21 days. Fetal monitoring REQUIRED (continuous fetal heart rate monitoring). Delivery if fetal distress. Neonatal antibiotics if neonatal infection suspected. Future pregnancies: Not contraindicated (not a chronic infection). Prevention: Avoid high-risk foods (deli meats, soft cheeses, unpasteurized dairy, smoked seafood, raw sprouts).
